uk.ac.kcl.informatics.opmbuild
Class Graph

java.lang.Object
  java.util.AbstractCollection<Account>
      uk.ac.kcl.informatics.opmbuild.Graph
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Iterable<Account>, java.util.Collection<Account>, Annotated
public class Graph
extends java.util.AbstractCollection<Account>
implements Annotated

Represents an OPM graph, possibly still in the process of being completed. As a data structure, a Graph is a Collection of Accounts, each of which contain the graph elements in those accounts (where one element can be in multiple accounts). A Graph starts with one special Account, called the no account, always present, which is the container for any elements not in an (explicit) account. A Graph can be annotated.

Author:
Simon Miles

add

public void add(GraphElement elementInNoAccount)
Convenience method to add a graph element into the no account. To avoid confusion, it is best to use this method only when not using accounts (so treating the graph as one unbroken collection of graph elements).

Parameters:
elementInNoAccount - The element to add to the graph/no account.

getElements

public java.util.Set<GraphElement> getElements()
Returns all graph elements in all accounts in this graph. Note that this includes effects and causes of all edges in the graph, regardless of whether they were independently added to an account.

Returns:
The set of elements in this graph as a whole

Parameters:

Returns:
True if this is the no account

noAccount

public Account noAccount()
Returns the set of graph elements not in any account. To add an element with no account, simply add it to this set.

Returns:
The no account for this graph

remove

public void remove(GraphElement elementInNoAccount)
Convenience method to remove a graph element from the no account. To avoid confusion, it is best to use this method only when not using accounts (so treating the graph as one unbroken collection of graph elements).

Parameters:
elementInNoAccount - The element to remove from the graph/no account.
